title: Tuesday, 14th June, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE

Hey! Hello, good morning, fancy seeing you here.

BE

No Paul today.

BE

Meaning it's up to me to do the preamble.

11:03 am
BE

So let's start with a quick look at the 10-year bund

BE

BE

And at the Brexit polls ..........

11:03 am
BE

BE

Okay ... So what's the latest on the American election?

BE

11:04 am
BE

And finally, the FTSE.

BE

BE

So, fine.

11:04 am
BE

Everything's just fine.

BE

In numerical form, we're down another 1.2%.

BE

Off 71 points at 5974

11:05 am
BE

(And my decade-old advice of selling the FTSE at 6k is back in profit.)

BE

(Bloody hell, rabble. You don't recognise the penultimate scene in Rebel Without a Cause?)

BE

(Go switch this nonsense off and watch the movie. We won't mind. You'll come back tomorrow a better, more ad-valuable person.)

11:07 am
BE

Sterling's at a two-month low .....

BE

.... though reading too much into sterling might be foolhardy given yesterday's nonsense

BE

Which was, to summarise, a deathly unfunny parody Twitter account made a rubbish joke and moved cable.

11:09 am
BE

Followed closely by a bunch of people not understanding what retweets are, and also moving cable.

BE

All hinging on ICM's website crashing.

BE

Here's The Globe and Mail's syndicated Bloomberg copy on that one: http://www.theglob...l/article30424152/

11:11 am
undefined
BE

So, Premier Farnell.

Premier Farnell PLC (PFL:LSE): Last: 163.50, up 54.25 (+49.66%), High: 164.25, Low: 162.00, Volume: 17.34m
11:12 am
BE

Daetwyler of Switzerland pays £615m for the widget distributor.

BE

165p, a 51% premium.

BE

There was speculation -- quite recently in fact -- of interest from China and the US.

11:14 am
BE

Appeared in a few market reports, though it felt a bit low quality.

BE

The stronger rumours were back in October.

BE

Which will make the timeline on this one interesting reading, once we finally learn it.

11:15 am
BE

Because it's sensible to keep the Panel on their toes.

BE

Let me grab some of Olivetree's deal summary.

BE

Given the presence of activists on the register, and the general underperformance of Premier Farnell stock, the market has often speculated as to a creative outcome for the company. One of the more popular ideas in the last couple of years has been a merger with Electrocomponents (ECM LN). The latter established a new management team only last year, replacing a previous CEO who had run the company for 13 years, so there was hope that such developments could lubricate such a transaction. There were also calls for a break up of Premier Farnell, the pressure was to sell its Akron Brass fire-fighting subsidiary, perceived to be a poor fit with the larger electronics business. This sale was eventually announced in September last year and the details of the sale were confirmed in February 2016. Hence the next step for activists was likely to be consolidation with another industry player – something we are now seeing today.

11:16 am
BE

Datwyler has secured irrevocables from 18.5% of Premier Farnell’s register, from JO Hambro, Majedie and (activist) GO Investment Partners. These irrevocables generally release in the event of an offer from a third party that is only 5% better than the Datwyler offer (ie 173.25p).

BE

It is worth noting that Electrocomponents equity rating continues to look powerful relative to that of Premier Farnell, so a potential merger could continue to make sense. Rumours of such a transaction have never been far from the market, as recently as 9th October 2015 the press reported such speculation. The perception was generally that GO had taken its stake, post two profit warnings from Premier Farnell, in order to engineer such a tie-up. The industry backdrop continues to appear ripe for consolidation, so such a transaction cannot be entirely ruled out, especially given that Datwyler’s irrevocables are released so easily. With a current market cap of £1.2bn, Electrocomponents is much larger than Premier Farnell, although it is still smaller than Datwyler’s £1.7bn market cap. Electrocomponents’ equity currently trades on some 10.8x EV/EBITDA, compared with Premier’s 6.5x, so it does have a powerful acquisition currency, both on a relative and absolute basis:

Electrocomponents PLC (ECM:LSE): Last: 264.80, down 12.5 (-4.51%), High: 287.90, Low: 264.00, Volume: 1.05m
11:17 am
BE

Not entirely sure what that ECM price is reflecting, nor the extremely high volume.

BE

It might be expressing a worry that ECM gets drawn into an expensive counterbid.

BE

Or it might be telling us that ECM's natural partner to achieve global scale has grown tired of waiting and has gotten itself engaged to someone else.

11:19 am
BE

... Though Premier's not at a price that's expecting a counter. So, dunno.

BE

RBC incoming.

BE

Our view: The 165p cash offer compares well with our previous 155p
target and given weak trading, historic issues, management change and
gross margin pressures, we feel this is a good price, although wouldn't
rule out a counterbid. We downgrade to Sector Perform and increase our
target to 165p in line with the bid from Daetwyler.

11:20 am
BE

Key points:
Recommended cash offer - Daetwyler has made a recommended cash
offer at a 51% premium to last night's close of 165p per share, which
values the group at £792m. This compares to our prior DCF target price
of 155p and equates to a calendar 2016E PE of 16x and EV/EBITA of 12x.
Shareholders will also receive the 3.6p final dividend payable on 23 June.
Management believes it can extract CHF50-70m (£37-51m) synergies from
the deal (50% gross profit and 50% cost).

BE

Decent price - Given weak trading, the history of disappointments,
management change, gross margin pressures, and the cycle - we see
this as a good price. However, the valuation is below that of key peer
Electrocomponents,(2016E PE 20x, EV/EBITDA 16x). The synergy target
is a big number for a business that doesn't have huge overlap, hence
we would think that the synergy number for one of the closer peers
e.g. Electrocomponents would be larger - indeed we have previously
stated that we think £60m could be achieved by a combination with it,
although the new management team has plenty on its plate with its own
restructuring plans. Mouser and Digikey in the US also have good overlap
and a strong dollar potentially to entice them. As such, despite this being
a good price we wouldn't rule out a counterbid.

BE

Q1 Trading weak - PFL has also put out a Q1 trading update – LFL growth
was -1.4% down from +0.4% in Q4, with weakness in the UK (-7%) and USA
(-9%) offset by Europe (+4.8%) and Asia (+26%). Cost savings do appear to
be on track and management has initiated some restructuring in the USA.

11:21 am
BE

Downgrade to Sector Perform - Given our view that this is a fair price,
we downgrade to Sector Perform and increase our target price to 165p,
in line with the offer. This compares to our previous DCF derived target
price of 155p.

undefined
BE

Because I guess there's not enough Microsoft-Linkedin comment out there already, that's where the ROTR has headed.

11:22 am
BE

And, since we're all about audience engagement mow, I guess we can kick it around for a moment.

BE

"This may seem like sour grapes but we don’t buy the Microsoft Kool aid," writes Neil Campling at Northern Trust, which is a good example of an extended metaphor.

BE

LinkedIn only has 105 million MAUs (Monthly Average Users) …aka people who have used LinkedIn once in the last 12 months, which itself has only grown 9% YoY. On the same metric Facebook is 15x larger. Microsoft has just paid $247 for each one of these users. On the same metric, Twitter would be worth $70 billion in valuation rather than $10 billion the market affords it today.

11:24 am
BE

Yep.

BE

Microsoft claim that in connecting the world’s leading professional cloud with the world’s leading professional network, the combination can create more connected, intelligent and productive experiences. Unification. That it can break down silos. But therein lies the issue…. Microsoft is one great big combination of disintegrated, fragmented silos. And the way LinkedIn will be treated suggests more of the same. After all, unification requires significant data integration and data sharing across the platform. But Microsoft is already weak in data integration across its own services. There is a distinct lack of unification from Skype and Bing to Outlook and Word for example.

BE

Such integration asks a key question. Which of the Microsoft’s databases should it be integrated with? Access? Office 365? Azure? SQL Server? Etc. Microsoft can’t even integrate its own databases, platforms and services. If there is real integration and synergies then why is LinkedIn to continue to operate independently of Microsoft?

11:25 am
BE

Yep.

BE

Microsoft’s acquisition history is littered with disasters. From the deal to buy the Facebook you’ve never heard of, Yammer, and Skype to the likes of aQuantive (writing off 98% of $6.2 billion purchase price) and Nokia (a $7.6 billion write off in excess of the $7.2bn paid for the phone unit).

BE

Yep.

11:26 am
BE

There is only one clear winner from the Microsoft/LinkedIn deal. The LinkedIn employees who have enjoyed the significant employee compensation in recent times.

BE

Yep.

BE

I'll save the rest for clients of Northern Trust, which you should already be if you read Campling's stuff here with any regularity.

11:27 am
BE

On the flipside, Canaccord.

BE

If you had asked us who Microsoft might buy, we wouldn’t have placed LinkedIn in the
top tier of most likely. Some of this thinking is due to our narrow purview on business
software versus Internet (where LinkedIn was typically covered), but also because
Microsoft previously had modest to no effort in talent acquisition and B2B marketing.
In some ways, this acquisition reminds us of when Adobe bought Omniture. At the
time, we were surprised, but a few years later, Omniture looks to have been a smart
purchase that really moved forward the strategic vision.
More broadly, there are some other ways to think of this purchase – both on an
offensive and defensive basis. On the latter, there was some rumbling among
investors that Microsoft’s mobile presence was comparatively thin, especially after the
write off and slimmed down ill-fated Nokia purchase. Obviously, Nokia is not LinkedIn,
but there is no question that LinkedIn has a substantial and impressively growing
mobile presence. We continue to believe Microsoft has taken a logical step in not
trying to compete in the pricing race to the bottom world that you see in the mobile
phone business (the fact is that there are far better positioned companies in that
space).
On the cloud side of the equation, LinkedIn has at least some fit to Microsoft’s three
clouds: Azure, Dynamics and Office 365. On the former, more volume through the
Azure infrastructure generates scale for that effort. We are less bullish on Dynamics
than Microsoft’s commentary, but we certainly believe Dynamics becomes more
valuable if you, as a salesperson, can pull in data from the employment social graph
that LinkedIn has established. There are a few dozen “sales acceleration tools”
vendors out there who are growing rapidly, so at least anecdotally this growth bodes
well for a combined Microsoft-LinkedIn effort. Finally, it is pretty self-evident how
Office apps, basically email, sync in well with LinkedIn.

BE

Of course, when you spend $26+ billion, you have a large transaction with associated
risks, the first of which is integration. At least initially, Microsoft will keep most of
LinkedIn as a separate subsidiary. This makes particular sense when it comes to the
talent management/recruiting side of LinkedIn (about 65% of revenues). Longer term,
we continue to believe that if and as Microsoft gets more aggressive in enterprise
applications, the firm will need to bolster its enterprise sales effort. By this we mean
either something like Salesforce’s hiring of Keith Block or Oracle hiring Mark Hurd. Of
course, talented people like that are not easy to find, so this sometimes leads to
future acquisitions. While this is a large transaction, we believe it is quite possible that
Microsoft will eventually consider buying a firm with exceptional sales talent. In our
opinion, firms with exemplary sales teams include Salesforce, Workday, Adobe,
ServiceNow and Splunk. While we doubt any of those firms want to be acquired and
acknowledge they are in disparate segments, there is no question each of those firms
have strong technology and sales franchises.
In conclusion, count us as surprised but positive on the purchase.

11:28 am
undefined
BE

Should we stick to M&A for a moment or two?

BE

Because I guess Aveva needs revisited, if only briefly.

11:30 am
AVEVA Group PLC (AVV:LSE): Last: 1,855, no change, Volume: 0.00
BE

Now suspended having popped nearly 10% on our story. which I guess is good and bad news.

BE

Hope at least a few of you got in there pre suspension, ROTR. The brokers wouldn't have helped you much.

11:32 am
BE

Caz, for instance .....

BE

Who rushed out this note between our story and the confirmation.

BE

Our view: It has been our long-held view that independent industrial software companies could be targets for global automation players given the theme of the industrial internet. We view these (expensive) acquisitions as much as “cost to stay in the game” as an incremental opportunity. By acquiring a number of software businesses and integrating them, Siemens has pushed ahead, putting pressure on other automation companies to follow. Hence we are not surprised that Aveva is speculated to be a target again. We are however surprised that Schneider is reportedly attempting to repeat a similar structure that failed last time. While we have somewhat more visibility on the outlook in oil & gas capex, Aveva’s most important end-market, the stock is no cheaper today than last summer, with the absolute share price similar to the level it was at prior to last
summer’s report that the two companies were in discussions. Aveva traded on 25.0x one year forward adj.
EPS on Bloomberg consensus on last Friday’s close which compares to a 23.5x adj. P/E multiple consensus last summer. The Aveva stock price is up 37% from the lows this year prior to today’s move and similar to the 1,765p of last summer before discussions were reported in the press.

11:33 am
BE

Then, post confirmation, came this .....

BE

Although no details were discussed, Aveva shares have been suspended, indicating potential deal announcement after market close.

BE

Uh, no.

11:33 am
BE

I guess it's understandable that an investment bank would assume the story had been dropped the story into the press immediately before the announcement. Keep things orderly, etc.

BE

But not all stories are dropped into the press by investment banks.

BE

Some come out in spite of the investment banks.

11:34 am
BE

Citi was also questioning the fact that it's a resurrection of last year's deal structure, in spite of it being a fact.

BE

On the failed transaction last year, Schneider had commented that it had underestimated the challenges in separating its software business to inject into Aveva, although it is not clear what has changed since – whether these separation issues have been resolved or whether Schneider sees increased urgency in scaling its existing software business.

BE

Then there's Berenberg, who downgraded.

11:02 am
BE

This is Markets Live, the FT's daily markets live thing.

BE

That I guess must've been signed off by compliance about 15 minutes before the story dropped

BE

Leaving no time to update. Not even in a footnote.

11:35 am
BE

● Shares are now close to our price target; down to Hold: We downgrade
AVEVA to Hold on valuation grounds. The shares have re-rated
significantly following management’s statement at the end of April. There
was a clear disconnect between the sell-side and the buy-side expectations
for both FY16 results and the outlook for FY17 going into results. However,
when management confirmed the outlook without the “expected” profit
warning, this sent the shares c15% higher than they were trading during
the quarter. We believe that the recurring revenue stream is a lot more
resilient than expected by financial analysts. Our analysis in January
(please see Back to basics) showed that rental contracts usually do not
decline, even when the oil price falls for more than one period. We believe
that the existing levels better represent the lack of short-term catalysts in
the core business (excluding M&A).

BE

Oof.

BE

Incidentally, the proposal we believe is currently on the table involves Schneider paying about £500m for a 51% stake of Aveva, as well as backing in the Software business on a theoretical valuation of about £1bn.

11:37 am
BE

Things can change quickly, though, and do.

BE

Panmure looks to have the most sensible take.

BE

M&A is so du jour in the tech sector right now. Old tech companies are getting
desperate lest they fall further behind in the new SMAC world. To wit:
Microsoft is buying Linkedin and old tech security Symantec is buying BlueCoat.
Next up Schneider Electric is gearing up to buy Aveva – this would be second
time lucky for Schneider. The pair tried and failed in the past (talks collapsed in
December, some blaming the French company’s larger size for a lack of focus on
completing the deal) but now Schneider, clearly bereft of other ideas, has
rekindled talks – well, maybe there’s been a bit of a tug from Aveva
shareholders thinking about that lost £10 per share. Any deal will give Aveva
rights to drive the direction at Schneider – having Mr Longdon at the helm is a
good idea. Last time the deal ran out of steam: this time expect Schneider to
make a sweeter deal for UK Aveva shareholders, so that £10 per share should
get supersized. The industrial logic remains that a deal helps Aveva dilute its
c40% Oil & Gas exposure, do better in America and have a larger portfolio to
sell to its (loyal) customers. Aveva also has a team who can make the big plays.
Yes, we would prefer Aveva to remain independent but this will work for Aveva
shareholders. Caveat: beware the two to three years of clash clash bang bang as
Aveva fixes Schneider Electric. Thereafter, and of course, just before Aveva
shares ‘turn’, Schneider will buy the lot thereby giving (i) Aveva shareholders a
second payday and (ii) Aveva’s well-regarded management team an
opportunity to write their own succession plan. Expect a deal to value Aveva at
more than c£22 per share – accordingly, we move to Buy.

11:38 am
BE

And if we made money for you yesterday, feel free to give a little back: http://ftalphavill...s-london-hac-july/

undefined
BE

ROTR: yep, we're watching the Teathers Financial story.

11:39 am
BE

Having followed it from the outset, here and elsewhere.

BE

It's the kind of story that needs very careful phrasing though, given the gravity of what might have gone on. Expect coverage later, in a more controlled forum.

undefined
11:42 am
BE

Cripes, requests for gold and silver.

BE

Let me see what's around, though "gold research" often feels like an oxymoron.

BE

In the meantime, buses.

11:43 am
Go-Ahead Group PLC (GOG:LSE): Last: 2,029, down 404.1 (-16.61%), High: 2,250, Low: 2,026, Volume: 157.86k
FirstGroup PLC (FGP:LSE): Last: 106.60, up 3.5 (+3.39%), High: 116.10, Low: 98.25, Volume: 3.87m
BE

Both say everything's in line.

11:44 am
BE

Detail, though, is strikingly different.

BE

Go-ahead's problem is a margin guidance cut at GTR.

BE

Or Govia Thameslink Railway, as its customers know it.

11:45 am
BE

Here's what the downgrades look like. Morgan Stanley ..........

BE

Go-Ahead has reported overall trading over the 4Q has been in line, and the
group's FY expectations for both Bus and Rail are unchanged. GOG continues
to expect £100m of FY Bus profit on an adjusted basis. Notably, however, the
group now expects margins of the lifetime of the GTR franchise to be closer to
1.5%, vs. 3% expected previously. As previously reported, the additional
investment GOG has made into GTR to support service delivery is depressing
margins for this year and will also impact next year’s margins. While margins
are expected to improve in the longer term, given the "very challenging
performance and industrial relations environments", GOG no longer expects to
recover the profit shortfalls. We currently assume 3% in our model for GTR
to 2022: putting this to 1.5% lowers our F2017 EPS estimate by c. 3-4% and
our F2018 EPS by c. 8%.

BE

In Regional Bus, GOG reported +2.1% revenue growth over the year, with
broadly stable pax vols of -0.2%, despite ongoing weakness in the North East.
In London Bus, revenue growth totalled +6.0%, implying an improvement in
4Q, with +2.2% mileage growth. Across Rail, London Midland reported solid
rev growth of +11% for the FY, underpinned by solid pax vols at +8%.
Southeastern also reported solid FY growth of +5% and vols of +2.3%. At
GTR, rev growth was stable at +3.1%.

11:46 am
BE

(I think that autotext is Southeastern, and is probably from back when Neil Hume was on here.)

BE

(Trains are the bane of Neil's life.)

BE

And ........... Jefferies? I think they're house.

11:47 am
BE

GOG has halved its expectations for GTR's franchise life margins to 1.5% (adj
basis). As ever with Rail, perspective is key. P&L impact is one thing, but the lost
opportunity is for us defined by remaining franchise life (just over 5-years for
GTR's contracted term) & GOG's ownership level (65%). GTR's contribution to
our SOTP falls £98m (228p per share) vs the group mkt cap of £1046m (2433p
share price). A disappointment yes, but we think a contained one.

BE

GTR guidance cut - In an unscheduled update, GOG's full year expectations for both its
rail & bus are unchanged (sees the latter at £100m on an adjusted basis). But it guides
contract life margins (adjusted basis) on GTR closer to 1.5% vs 3% before, due to sustaining
costs for longer to deliver franchise performance. This is steered to impact FY17 franchise
margins and we see the period beyond the introduction of new train fleets (by end of 2018)
as the opportunity to achieve levels above the contract life average steered.

BE

Forecast changes focus on rail - Adopting the rail guide moves our FY16 FY17 FY18
eps forecasts down by 2.0% 9.4% 16.5%. GTR is a big contract (c.£1.3bn revs pa) and the
margin claw back in future years from around breakeven (JEFe) this year will be less marked
than previously assumed.

11:48 am
BE

Rail best considered through SOTP - our long held view is that rail franchise
contributions to group P&Ls can often be overstated in the sense that they are typically
large in quantum but increasingly short lived (all contracts are converging on expiry).
Contribution to value through the SOTP is, for us, a better focus for rail activities. The
contribution of GTR to our SOTP falls by 228p per share.
Read through - with Stagecoach also facing challenges on East Coast, another of the
latest wave of franchise awards, there are undoubtedly discussions to follow around the
competitive conditions in the bidding market and the terms groups are feeling compelled
to offer to secure new contracts.
Valuation/Risks
Our reworked SOTP points us to a new price target of 2775p (from 3030p before). Whilst
our DPS forecasts do follow our eps forecasts lower (group policy is c2x covered by pre
IAS19 eps), we see of a yield of 4.5% this year rising to 5% in FY18. Risks incl. missing the
bus EBIT target, developments in the DfT's rail franchising programme, rail profitability can
be lumpy, & regulatory risks (incl the Buses Bill).

Stagecoach Group PLC (SGC:LSE): Last: 235.50, down 12.7 (-5.12%), High: 245.70, Low: 235.30, Volume: 517.47k
BE

And RBC as well, just for the full set.

11:48 am
BE

Our View - Yield, growth potential problems with GTR profit warning: Go-Ahead continues to see FY expectations on track with outlook but with GTR based profit warning
now seeing life of contract margin lower - at likely 1.5% not 3%. The shares still yield ~4% but with GTR rebasing down (again) we see risk of 10-13% 2017E-2018E
consensus EPS cuts, lifting forward PER to over 15x. GTR has a 6 year finite life, but the development - together with FGP LN's weak UK Bus trading since April - is not
helpful.
Overall, this UK centric company remains hostage to events. The UK Buses Bill seems to have muted overall threats - looking manly limited to North East Bus revenues in
the long-term (3% group revenues, 9% EBIT). However, a UK EU referendum out vote could damage margin prospects - if consumer demand in Bus and rail falls and should
imported (USD) fuel costs rise.

BE

1. Regional Bus improvement continued - with YTD revenues up 2.1% , volumes -0.2% so after H1 volume decline of 1% (and -0.5% in Q2), H2 has seen improved but still
lacklustre outlook. To deliver FY2015/16 outlook of £54.8m deregulated bus profits, H2 EBIT only needs to see marginal uplift on H1. Looking ahead, Go-Ahead is fully
hedged on fuel (at low rates) until 2019 which we see helping margins lift in future even as spot fuel prices rise. Adverse road works conditions should ease in Oxford from
October 2016, but the UK's generally deflationary Bus revenue backdrop and inflationary labour cost pressures remain a challenge, we think.
2. London bus: London saw mileage grow 2.2%, revenues by 6% even as the company has lost QICS payments due to worse (and likely structurally changed) London road
congestion problems. The new London mayor still has to answer the challenge of how bus services can be improved after the previous mayor removed road space for non
bicycle users - including buses - that has led to a recent and unprecedented (in the last decade) decline in London bus use. For bus operators the fix will likely be funding to
run more vehicles, with TFL likely to also be required to fund the mayor's manifesto pledge to equalise bus driver pay between operators.

Go-Ahead updated to its (53-week based) £100m EBIT goal for 2016/17E for all of its Bus operations. We forecast ~£97m - i.e., £95m annualised for a 52 week year, vs. RBCe
~£90m for 2015/16E. Go-Ahead now (only) expects to reach the £100m goal on an IAS19 (pension) adjusted basis which in H1 flattered EBIT by £0.7m.
3. Rail - UK economic deterioration on EU referendum uncertainty visible. Rail revenues continued to grow, but the growth rate decelerated (again). London rail demand
remains tightly linked to UK GDP prospects and to Central London Employment (CLE) changes. The pre EU referendum uncertainty - leading to UK GDP slowdown and lack
of company hiring - is visible in Go-Ahead's rail numbers at SET we think. SET revenues were up 5.1% for the year (vs. 9 month +5.5%), GTR up 3.1% (vs. 9 month +3%). The
bid process for LMR sees Go-Via (Go-Ahead and minority partner Keolis) shortlisted alongside MTR and an Abellio/Japanese consortium for the likely summer 2017 award
announcement.

BE

I wonder, if one were to add it up from the 19th century then inflation-link it, if there's been an industry that's consumed more money than rail?

11:50 am
BE

Airlines, perhaps.

BE

As for FirstGroup .... much less interesting.

FirstGroup PLC (FGP:LSE): Last: 107.20, up 4.1 (+3.98%), High: 116.10, Low: 98.25, Volume: 4.40m
11:51 am
BE

Bleak outlook, but not unexpectedly so.

BE

FY slightly ahead, UK bus and rail guidance trimmed, but no explicit warning.

BE

JP Morgan like them.

11:52 am
BE

(@jimpj: the big problem with air is that it also tends to require rail to get to the airport.)

BE

We retain our OW rating on FirstGroup following the FY16 prelims this
morning. The results are slightly ahead of our estimates, 4% at the PBT level
and 9% at the EPS level, owing to lower interest and tax, respectively.
Although industry challenges in the UK Bus and Rail divisions cause us to
lower our EPS estimates, -4%/-5% to FY17E/18E, the cashflow is stronger.
FY16 FCFe was better than our estimate and we increase our FY17E/18E
forecasts, with the stock now yielding 7%/8%. Despite the disappointment of
lower margins, reflecting slowing industry LFLs in both the bus and rail
sectors, we see a recovering cashflow as positive. We see valuations as
undemanding, at PERs of 8.7x/7.9x for FY17E/18E, with potential for long-
term improvement and dividend resumption as the group should be able to
refinance its significant bond portfolio at lower rates.

BE

 FY16 in line at the operating level, EPS ahead on lower interest/tax.
FirstGroup reported £301m of adjusted operating profit, in line with our
previously reduced estimate, and down -1% YoY, despite significant
challenges such as the effects of a lower oil price and UK Rail revenues
down -41% due to franchises coming to an end.

11:53 am
BE

 Earnings lower on industry challenges in UK bus/rail. LFL growth has
been slowing in both the UK bus and rail sectors recently and we update our
forecasts to account for this: we now forecast flat LFLs in UK Bus for
FY17E and a 7.0% margin (vs. 0.5% growth and 8.5% previously) and 3.0%
LFL in UK Rail and a 3.7% margin (vs. 3.2% and a 5.8% margin). A lack of
industry volume growth in UK Bus makes margin expansion more
challenging, and although cost and fuel savings are expected, expansion in
FY17E is below expectations. Rail is dragged down by lower LFLs as well
as the transition to the GWR direct award.

BE

 US divisions increased slightly. For the other divisions, which represent
63% of profit, we increase estimates slightly, reflecting an outperformance
vs. our FY16 estimates and a slightly more favourable FX environment.
Cost overruns due to driver shortages have impacted the group in FY16, and
the group now expects margins of at least 9.0% in FY17E, implying at least
+175bps of margin expansion.

undefined
11:54 am
BE

Cripes, time does pass doesn't it?

BE

I guess we should mention Ocado, though there's nothing specific to say yet.

BE

Well, apart from chucking up this graph.

11:55 am
BE

BE

Markit short interest to free float, going all the way back to 2010.

BE

I promised bullion research, so here's bullion research.

BE

Citi does Brexit and Gold, which I guess is a big overlap in the "people you block on Twitter" venn diagram.

12:01 pm
BE

The UK referendum on EU membership has implications across many asset classes but gold, as the ultimate barometer of financial and economic tension, is currently the asset class showing one of the highest levels of sensitivity to the possible range of outcomes. In today’s MMM we track how that gold has fluctuated in line with the opinion polls, even dislocating it from its usual primary-link with the US dollar. We also study the implications for mining equities of the referendum outcome.

In our study, we do not express any opinion on the likely outcome. For that, we would refer our readers to numerous research documents which have been written by Citi analysts on the subject. (Global Political Focus: Is the UK Public Flirting With Brexit? Will It Continue?; Brexit & UK Banks: Two Weeks To Go – Possible Implications;Brexit and UK Diversified Financials: 14 days to go – Recap of our thoughts on different outcomes).

BE

Our focus is on examining how gold has responded so far to the Brexit average voting-poll trends (as shown in Figure 1 of the Global Political Focus document referred to above) in order to establish if gold is paying any attention to the referendum at all. In Figure 1 below, within the large rectangle, it is clear that gold’s price-boost in January was accompanied by a sharp move towards the anti-Europe voters (indicated by a fall in the bold line during January and February).

BE

12:01 pm
BE

Similarly (and more recently) the June-2016 rally in gold occurred at a time of a similar sharp move towards and anti-Europe outcome. For most of April and May, the vote trend was range-bound (mostly between 1.0 and 5.0, as per the left-hand axis) but when that voting level rose rapidly from 2.0 to 8.0 in the second half of May, it was accompanied by a fall in gold from $1280 to $1200.

These trends are enough to suggest that gold has been highly-sensitive to the trend in the poll but we also need to establish if the US dollar was behaving in the same way, because gold is very sensitive to the dollar and it might have been taking its cue from the dollar rather than from Brexit poll- trend.

BE

Figure 2 shows the relationship between gold and the USA dollar and, as one would expect, gold is mostly inversely correlated with the dollar, with dollar strength typically resulting in gold weakness.

BE

12:02 pm
BE

Dollar-weakness did begin during early February, which coincided with the move to anti-Europe sentiment depicted in the large triangle in Figure 1. So, on that occasion, the dollar weakened in tandem with the rise in anti-European sentiment. At the same time, the Japanese Yen (which could possibly have become the ‘go-to’ insurance in the event of a UK-exit) strengthened. We cannot therefore argue that the shift towards anti-EU sentiment was the primary driver of gold at that time. It may be that the Yen-Dollar relationship had the strongest correlation to the vote-trend and that gold was simply responding to that.

However, the behavior of gold during the weakness in the dollar depicted between the parallel lines above (March/April) shows that gold completely ignored the weakening dollar (gold should have risen quite sharply) and, instead, gold followed the sideways and range-bound trend in the Brexit poll-trend.

This is very educational in terms of the cause and effect relationship between Brexit, gold and the dollar. During those parallel lines, gold seems to have had ‘a mind of its own’ and shown itself to possibly be the PRIMARY asset-class in terms of a link with Brexit. In other words, gold has followed the Brexit-poll as long as the dollar/yen is also following the Brexit trend. When the dollar has dislocated from the Brexit trend (possibly because of other considerations such as an updated view on future US interest rates) gold has dislocated from the dollar as well.

During the credit-crisis and in its aftermath, gold was the ultimate barometer of global financial nervousness, even more so than the dollar or the VIX index. It seems that, at this major juncture in the European political and economic set-up, gold could once more be the ultimate barometer of market tension.

BE

In Figure 4 below we see that European equities are currently little-changed from their January 2016 levels, despite quite a big move towards and anti-Europe stance in the Brexit-poll since then. There is therefore one key counter-argument to the thesis that gold is the ultimate barometer of financial-market tension. The subdued volatility in equity markets at a time of high-volatility in the Brexit poll could mean that the equity markets have somehow seen through that poll-volatility as a ‘storm in a teacup’.

BE

12:04 pm
BE

I'm skipping a bit, so Citi doesn't feel it necessary to shout at me later.

BE

Skipping to the question: "Should I be buying gold shares if I believe that the UK will remain within the EU?"

BE

The answer to that question could be different to the answer to this question: “Should I be buying gold metal if I believe that the UK will remain within the EU?”. Toronto shares, in general, are undoubtedly influenced by the trends south of the border in the S&P composite index. When gold fell from $1296 to $1200 during May, Toronto gold shares showed no signs of negativity at all. This was likely due to the subdued response by the S&P to the Brexit poll-trend.

12:05 pm
BE

If an investor believes that the UK will remain in the EU and that this will reduce investor-tension and hence reduce gold’s role as a tension-monitor, he may be wrong to conclude that he should therefore be selling his gold shares in anticipation of a ‘remain-outcome’ (or the converse for an ‘Exit-outcome’.) The S&P chart, from a technical point of view, looks as though it is currently spring-loaded for the upside, pending a positive outcome for the referendum. Even if gold were to go down on any possible outcome, it is likely that Toronto gold shares will piggy-back on the general North-American equity market trends.

As a mining team we do not take a view on the referendum outcome but we ascribe to the Citi view of a Remain outcome as the most likely scenario from the referendum.

BE
